Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract The concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere is rapidly increasing, posing serious environmental concerns. It is preferable to use CO2 as a feedstock for fine chemicals and fuel synthesis to address this challenge successfully. Herein, we report the synthesis of bimetallic oxide composite with significantly lower wt.% of active Ru loaded on spinel cubic phase Co3O4 oxide support. The synthesized catalyst formed cubic Ru-Co3O4 (Ruthenium and Cobalt oxide) nanocrystalline surface morphology with active Ru+3/+4 and Co+2/+3 oxidation states under hydrothermal conditions. The synthesized Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst facilitated the reduction of CO2 to formic acid under tailored conditions. The 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited highest formic acid yield (250 mmol) with a high turnover number of 182 under the mild reaction conditions, 1:1 CO2 and H2 (62 bar) gas pressure, 120 °C in 6 h. Ru-supported Co3O4 catalyst captures CO2 through the base. The activated CO2 is then hydrogenated to formic acid. The catalyst can be reused for multiple cycles without losing any activity due to its alkali tolerant properties. The study offers a simple synthesis and efficient industrially viable heterogeneous catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation. Keywords Heterogeneous catalyst Metal oxide CO2 utilization Formic acid Energy transformation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The global energy demand is exponentially increasing due to better livelihood standards, increasing the carbon footprint. In the current scenario, most energy sectors primarily use carbon-rich fossil fuels, emitting a large amount of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. According to IPC 2018 global report, 33.9 Gt of CO2 was emitted, and this amount is expected to rise with each passing year [1]. The atmospheric CO2 level and emission can be controlled by three different strategies; i) recovering and recycling CO2, ii) capturing and storing CO2, but from an economic point of view, geological storage of CO2 is expensive and energy inefficient, and iii) utilizing captured CO2 for value-added fine chemical synthesis [2,3]. As a result, there is a great deal of interest in producing value-added chemicals and fuel from CO2, such as carbonate, urea, salicylic acid, methanol, ether, and polycarbonate [4,5]. For instance, methanol has been successfully produced on a pilot-plant scale through CO2 hydrogenation [6–8]. Another promising strategy to utilize CO2 is direct hydrogenation to formic acid (FA). It provides liquid hydrogen storage, renewable hydrogen, and a new chemical source with significant industrial and academic applications [9]. Interestingly, it has been extensively investigated using homogeneous catalysts such as Pd, Ni, Cu, and Fe, containing complexes of C, N-, phosphorous, N, N-chelated, N Heterocyclic carbine (NHC), and pincer type ligands [10]. The main disadvantage of these catalytic systems is the difficulty in separation from the formic acid/formate due to the formation of adducts. To overcome this challenge, easily separable heterogeneous catalysts are highly desirable. Notably, only a few groups are working on developing heterogeneous catalysts; however, they have achieved lower formic acid concentrations [11–13]. In addition, CO2 can be hydrogenated through photocatalytic and electrochemical reduction methods. This acme is the growing demand for CO2 hydrogenation and catalyst-design to improve catalytic activity and recyclability, which is required to develop heterogeneous industrial catalysts [14–16]. Furthermore, there have been reports on using various mixed metal oxides (MMOs) for CO2 hydrogenation due to their enhanced reductive catalytic activity and increased dispersion properties [17]. Particularly, Pandey et al. reported that Cu dispersed on TiO2-supported catalyst was effective in batch reactor yielding formic acid with the highest TON of 6.64 [18]. Liu et al. used nanorods like Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and obtained formic acid yields of 13.6 mmol [19]. Continuous hydrogenation of CO2 using Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst has been reported at milder reaction conditions (140 °C and 30 bar). The maximum CO2 conversion rate of 13.1% was achieved with a formic acid yield of 7.6% and a TOF of 2.06 h − 1 [20]. The same group also reported that using Cu/CuCr2O4 catalyst increased CO2 conversion (14.63%) with formic acid yield (12.84%) and gave a TOF of 0.84 h − 1 [21]. Given the disadvantages of the various catalysts, we propose to synthesize a robust cobalt-based ruthenium oxide catalyst, in-depth characterization, and its role in achieving selective hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid under mild operating conditions. The catalysts were synthesized by varying the wt.% of Ru on Co3O4 via the co-precipitation method followed by hydrothermal treatment. The synthesized Ru-Co3O4 catalyst was found to be nanocrystalline with active Ru+3/+4 and Co+2/+3 electronic state. Remarkably, it demonstrated an efficient catalytic combination that leads to a high yield of formic acid. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials RuCl3.xH2O (Aldrich, 99%), Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99.5%, SRL India), Ammonia solution 25% (Finar, India). NaOH (96% SDFCL), KOH (85% SRL), Triethylamine (99.5% Loba Chemie), Diethylamine, H3PO4 (98% Avra), H2, and CO2 gas were received from Raj sons Bhavnagar, India. 2.2 Synthesis of Ru-Co3O4 catalyst The catalysts with different wt.% of Ru loaded on Co3O4 oxide were synthesized through co-precipitation, followed by the hydrothermal method. In a typical synthesis, 10 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 50 mL of distilled water and magnetically stirred for 10 min. Then, 0.5 g RuCl3.H2O was added to the reaction mixture and stirred until complete metal salt dissolution. Then 5.7 mL of 6.3 M NaOH solution was added dropwise as a co-precipitating agent, keeping constant pH of the reaction mixtures between 9 and 10 followed by aging for 24 h at room temperature. This reaction mixture was transferred into Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and treated at 120 °C for 5 h. After the hydrothermal process was completed, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered and washed with a copious amount of water and methanol until the filtrate turned to neutral pH. The obtained solid material was dried in a hot-air oven at 70 °C overnight. Finally, the obtained material was calcined for 5 h at 600 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C/min in an open-air electric muffle furnace. 2.3 The catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the synthesized Ru-Co3O4 catalysts were tested in a 300 mL stainless steel batch reactor. The reactor was charged with a 100 mL 0.76 M trimethylamine solution as a solvent and a freshly prepared 200 mg Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst. Then the reactor was packed and flushed thrice with N2 gas to remove any containment gasses. The reactor was pressurized with a 1:1 mixture of H2 and CO2 gas (total pressure 62 bar). The reactor was heated under slow stirring to the desired reaction temperature and time. After completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, and catalyst was filtered using simple Whatman filter paper, washed, dried, and reused for the next cycle. The obtained reaction product solution was analyzed by HPLC (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography) (JASCO, CO-2060 Plus, Intelligent column thermostat, MD-2015 Multiwavelength Detector, PU-2089 Quaternary Gradient Pump) with column C-610H and 0.1 NH3PO4 as a mobile phase. The column temperature was kept at 30 °C, the mobile phase flow rate 0.6 mL/min, and the signal was collected at 210 nm using a UV detector. The formic acid yield was quantified in mmol. A calibration curve was generated using a standard formic acid solution in the range of 2.5 to 400 mmol with 0.76 molar triethylamine to quantify the formic acid yield. The reaction product was also confirmed with 1H and 13C NMR and FT-IR (See in SI, S10). Then TON and TOF of the catalyst were calculated based on the metal loading observed from the Inductive Couple Plasma (ICP-OES) analysis results. 3 Result and discussion The different wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalysts were prepared using the co-precipitation followed by the hydrothermal method (Scheme 1 ). The aqueous complex of both metal salts was obtained by dissolving in an aqueous solution in basic media. Thus, the obtained hydration complex to crystals oxide under the hydrothermal condition. The hydrothermal process generates the autogenous pressure to produce monomer, which is then followed by nucleation and crystal growth before being calcined at a higher temperature (Scheme 2 ) [22]. The synthesized catalyst was characterized by various analytical techniques to identify the surface morphology, crystal structure, surface area, pore size, physical state and to determine the active surface site. The powder X-ray diffraction method was used to determine the phase purity of the synthesized catalysts (Fig. 1 ). The synthesized Ru-Co3O4 catalysts showed sharp diffraction peaks at 2θ = 19.5°, 31.3°, 36.6°, 38.5°, 44.8°, 55.5°, 59.3°, 65.1°, and 76.5° corresponding to (1 1 1), (2 2 0), (3 1 1), (2 2 2), (4 0 0), (4 2 2), (5 1 1), (4 4 0) and (5 3 3) planes, respectively. The 2θ value and corresponding planes confirm the spinel cubic phase of Co3O4, and it is in good agreement with (JCPDS-04–003–0984) file [23]. Due to the small particle size of the Ru oxide the corresponding active Ru oxide diffraction peak was not observed. The crystal size of cubic phase Co3O4 is determined using Debye Scherer's equation (See ESI, S2), in which the high-intensity peak at 2θ - 36.3° in cubic Co3O4 is used to determine the crystal size, which was 44.3 Å, and average crystalline size of Co3O4 (determined to be 17.2 Å). The textural properties of Ru-supported Co3O4 catalysts, such as pore volume and specific surface area, were measured using N2 adsorption and desorption measurement through the multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Prior to measuring the specific surface area and pore volume, all samples were degassed at 300 °C for 4 h. The results of N2 adsorption and desorption at the liquid nitrogen temperature are summarized in Table 1 . The H3 type hysteresis and monolayer adsorption of all samples are shown in (ESI-S5 Figure S4). The surface area of pure Co3O4 oxide is significantly lower 18.3 m2/g than Ru loaded on the Co3O4 oxide catalyst series, and the pore size of pure Co3O4 is 446 Å. The surface area of synthesized 0.58, 1.78, 2.69, and 4.7 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst gradually increased from 21 to 52.8 m2/g (Table 1). The specific surface area of 0.58 to 4.7 wt.% loading of Ru on Co3O4 was found to be increasing order; it may be due to increased Ru content or crystal growth on the Co3O4 matrix, which expands its structure, with decreasing particle size or increasing specific surface area. Furthermore, the pore size trends from initial Ru loading 0.58 to 2.9 sequentially increasing 226, 311, and 360 Å but less than pure Co3O4, and exceptionally 4.7 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 system suddenly increases the pore size up to 952 Å; a higher loading% of Ru on Co3O4 surfaces may affect the pore size. Fig. 2 depicts the FE-SEM images of 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst. The synthesized bimetallic oxide catalyst does not show any specific morphology. Fig. 2A shows the FESEM image of the freshly prepared 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 catalyst. Fig. 2B-D shows the elemental mapping of 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide system. Fig. 2D confirms that the Ru content is uniformly dispersed on the Co3O4 oxide surface. Fig. 2E shows the EDX of the synthesized catalyst. The Ru content in the catalyst was found intact even after the third cycle Figure ESI-S2A-D. Fig. 3 A shows the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) image of 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst. The spinel cubic Ru-Co3O4 oxide single crystalline phases are depicted in a sample with frequently separated lattice fringes 0.24, 0.44, 0.23, and 0.28 nm, which corresponds to (0 0 2), (3 1 1), (1 1 1), and (2 2 2) facet of Co3O4 oxide precisely and match with the d-spacing value (JCPDS-04–003–0984). Active Ru oxide is shown in Fig. 3A, displaying lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.20 and 0.21 nm are assigned (1 2 0) and (2 0 0) planes of Ru oxide (JCPDS-04–006–7473). This confirms that the Ru metal is mainly present in Ru oxide within the Co3O4 oxide [24]. Additionally, the SAED pattern in Fig. 3B having (3 1 1), (5 1 1), (6 6 2), and (6 6 4) plans of Co3O4 oxide (JCPDS-04–003–0984) and (1 3 1) plan of Ru oxide are present and confirmed with (JCPDS-04–006–7473). However, from the HRTEM analysis of 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxides particle size were found in the range of 10 to 30 nm (Fig. 3C) with 17.5 nm average particle size (ESI S4 Fig. 3A). High-resolution X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to investigate the chemical state of a solid surface Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst (XPS). The full survey spectra of the synthesized catalyst is shown in Fig. 4 A. The deconvolution of the Co 2p peak, shown in Fig. 4B, showed that the catalyst was primarily decomposed of two-centered Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 spin-orbits with binding energies of 795 and 779 eV, respectively. This indicated the presence of divalent and trivalent species in cubic Co3O4. The spectrum of Co3O4 has a peak at 779.7 eV that fitted into two components with binding energies 778.08 (FWHM-1.32) and 779.2 eV (FWHM-3.37) attributed to Co 2p3/2 spin-orbit splitting Co+2 and Co+3 respectively. While similar to the shoulder peak, binding energy at 795.2 eV split into two components with 794.4 (FWHM-2.9) and 796.1 eV (FWHM-1.5) related to the 2p1/2 spin orbits of Co+2 and Co+3 state, respectively. The typical Co shakeup peak at positions 786.6 (FWHM-3.3) and 804 eV (FWHM-4.1) can be conformed to Co+2, and Co+3 species present in cubic Co3O4 (Fig. 4B) [25]. Further, the chemical state of Ru in the prepared Ru-Co3O4 catalyst was investigated (Fig. 4C). The Ru 3d spectrum mainly illustrated two peaks, the spin-orbit splitting of Ru 3d5/2 and 3d3/2. The binding energy at 280.18 eV corresponds to Ru 3d5/2 (FWHM-1.77), which can be assigned to RuO2, indicating that the metal is in a + 4 oxidation state and the binding energy at 282.5 eV indicates a + 3 state of Ru in the catalyst [26]. Other shoulder peak spin-orbit of Ru 3d3/2 centered at binding energy 285.1 eV can be deconvoluted into two peaks, the binding energy at 284.2 and 286.5 eV corresponding to the Ru+4 state and Ru+3 state, respectively [27,28]. A less intense contaminated adventitious carbon peak position at binding energy at 284.1 eV was observed, but it has not interfered with the ruthenium peak Fig. 4C. The O 1 s spectra for the Ru-Co3O4 catalyst is shown in Fig. 4D. Two peaks at binding energies 528.3 and 529.5 eV were observed, the highly intense peak at 528.3 eV can be allocated to lattice oxygen O2−. In the spectrum, O2− binding energy can be ascribed to the different types of binding combinations with the cubic Co3O4 (Co+2/+3) surface of the catalyst [29]. The oxygen coordinated in the cubic Co3O4 system may be three oxygen coordinated with three Co+3 sites and two oxygen with Co+2 and Co+3 sites, a noticeable difference between the binding energy of O2 with Co3O4 [30]. However, the cubic Co3O4 attributed to the higher binding energy with O2 from the surface oxygen defect species proposes that the cubic Co3O4 structure has additional O2 vacancies that can be correlated with surface area and pore size analysis. The surface acidity and basicity of 2.9 wt.% Ru/Co3O4 oxide catalyst was quantified by the temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . The surface acidity of 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst was determined by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3 TPD) in an AutoChem HP 2950 V3.02A instrument with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The sample amount of 0.1 g was taken and He gas was passed at 100 °C for 1 h to remove the physisorbed water and other gasses, followed by cooling down the sample at room temperature. Further ammonia adsorption was carried out at the heating rate of 10 °C/min under flowing 2% NH3/He stream (30 mL/min) from temperature 100 °C to 700 °C. The TPD result of the Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst indicates the wide-ranging distribution of moderate acidic sites present in the catalyst. Typically, acidic strength determined by NH3 adsorption temperature range >400 °C can be attributed to the strong acidic sites [31]. Fig. 5 shows the NH3 TPD adsorption profile of the Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst. NH3 desorption peak at around 239.4, showing a weak acidic site and 575.6 °C, indicating the strong acidic sites were present. The quantitative NH3-TPD analysis of the catalysts with lower Ru content showed 1.23 mmol/g acidic sites in the material [32]. The Ru content in the series of Ru metal loaded on the Co3O4 oxide was confirmed by the Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) and the results showed 1.2, 3.3, 5.7, and 7.7 wt.% Ru metal in the Co3O4 catalyst. It was observed that the Ru concentration was slightly varied; the cobalt precursors might not be completely precipitated or consumed during the reaction, and the Ru precursor may be completely precipitated. The obtained. Ru's concentration was quite analogous to the theoretical value. The determined Ru concentration was used for determining the TON and TOF in catalytic activity. 4 CO2 hydrogenation activity of Ru-Co3O4 The synthesized Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst was used to convert CO2 to formic acid (Scheme 3 ). The investigation begins with the optimization of the catalytic amount for CO2 hydrogenation (Table 2 ). Initially, the reaction was performed only in distilled water and with trimethylamine without a catalyst, which did not lead to any CO2 conversion (Table 2, entries 1 and 2). However, when the reaction was carried out with simple Co3O4 oxide with trimethylamine, it was observed that the yield was found to be < 2 mmol formic acid (Table 2, entry 3). Next, CO2 hydrogenation was studied using different wt.% Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst. It was observed that increasing the Ru concentration on the Co3O4 oxide surface increased the formation of formic acid yield. Initially, 0.56 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 catalyst offered 107 mmol yields of formic acid (Table 2, entry 4) and 1.78 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 catalytic gave 187 mmol formic acid yield (Table 2, entry 5). In further studies, when 2.9 and 4.7 wt.% of Ru-Co3O4 catalysts were used, they provided an excellent yield of formic acid (250 and 310 mmol, respectively) (Table 2, entries 6 and 7). The leaching problem was observed in higher Ru-loaded catalyts for the first two cycles; thereafter cycles showed the same yield of formic acid. This happens due to a certain amount of Ru that is permanently grafted inside the Co3O4 framework, which was confirmed using SEM elemental mapping (See ESI figure S2). Hence 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 catalyst was chosen for further studies. The presence of a basic and acidic medium plays a vital role in the activation of CO2 at a lower temperature. CO2 activation in the basic medium is much easier because CO2 has a Lewis acidic character and thus acts as an electrophile and is easily activated by a base via a carbamate intermediate. Initially, the reaction was carried out without a base, which gave less than 5 mmol of the formic acid product (Fig. 6 A). Consequently, the catalytic activity in 0.1 molar alkaline bases such as KOH and NaOH yields formic acid of 14 and 22 mmol, respectively (Fig. 6A). Furthermore, an investigation was conducted in different types of amine-containing bases for hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid synthesis. With 3.9 molar aqueous NH3 as a base, it showed a minimal conversion of CO2 to the formic acid yield of 7 mmol as compared to other organo-amine bases (Fig. 6A). The catalytic activity of secondary amines such as diethylamine (0.1 molar in an aqueous solution) yielded 85 mmol yields of formic acid under the same reaction condition (Fig. 6A). According to the literature, triethylamine is commonly used as a base in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction due to its easy coordination with CO2 and its ability to promote the hydrogenation reaction [33]. In the case of triethylamine (0.76 molar), an excellent yield of 250 mmol formic acid was obtained (Fig. 6A). When compared to alkaline and other bases, triethylamine had the highest conversion. This occurred due to the reaction between CO2 and trimethylamine, which resulted in the formation of a carbamate intermediate. The carbamate intermediate was easily converted into formic acid. Therefore, triethylamine was chosen as a suitable base for further optimization studies. The effect of the reaction temperature (80 to 140 °C) on the hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid was also studied to see the rate of reaction (Fig. 6B). Since CO2 is a very rigid molecule, its activation at a lower temperature is difficult, which was the reason for the lower formic acid yield at 80 °C (Fig. 6B). Further increasing the reaction temperature from 80 to 100 °C, the formic acid yield increased marginally from 5 to 111 mmol (Fig. 6B). The highest yield of formic acid was obtained at 120 °C reaction temperature, giving 250 mmol of formic acid yield (Fig. 6B). A similar result was observed at 140 °C (Fig. 6B) or higher temperatures; the hydrogenation rate of CO2 was unchanged. Additionally, the gas ratio was also varied to optimize of use of gas. Initially, the reaction was carried out without adding H2, and as expected, there was no formation of formic acid, leading to the conclusion that no water splitting occurred that can generate H2 generation during the reaction in this reaction condition (Table 3 entry 1). When the reaction was carried out under 13.7, 27.5, and 41.3 bar (1:1) CO2 and H2 gas, a formic acid yield of in range 94, 97, and 178 mmol was obtained (Table 3, entries 2, 3, and 4). The change in the gas ratio (H2 pressure (300 psi) and CO2 (600 psi) pressure (1:2)) gave a formic acid yield of 210 mmol (Table 3 entry 5). When the gas ratio was kept (2:1 H2:CO2), the highest formic acid yield up to 300 mmol with the highest TON 219 was observed (Table 3 entry 6). The optimization study concluded that the CO2 hydrogenation to formic acid synthesis depended on catalyst loading, temperature, and pressure-dependent reaction. [39–42]. The rate of catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid synthesis as a function of time is shown in Fig. 7 . Initially, the yield of formic acid was high; 80 mmol of formic acid within 1 h. As the time increased from 1 to 6 h, the yield of formic acid also gradually increased from 80 to 250 mmol. After 6 to 10 h, the CO2 conversion rate suddenly decreased. At 10 h, 265 mmol yield of formic acid was observed. The time variation study concludes that after 6 h, there was the blocking of the active site of the catalyst, which led to the stopping of the CO2 adsorption and conversion to formic acid. After each reaction, the catalyst was successfully recovered using simple filtration, washed three times with water and methanol, and dried at 200 °C for 2 h. The collected catalyst was reused for further recycling experiments (ESI S8 figure S5). It was observed that there was a decrease in the yield of formic acid in the second cycle. However, the third and fourth cycles gave a constant yield of formic acid, as shown in (ESI S8 figure S5). The decrease in the formic acid product in the second cycle may be due to the leaching of the non-covalently bonded or anchored Ru atom from the Co3O4 oxide surface. However, the remaining third and fourth cycle gives a consistent performance for formic acid synthesis. This indicates that Ru is covalently incorporated within the Co3O4 oxide; hence even after two cycles, it gave the same yield of formic acid. 5 Spectroscopic study (NMR, FTIR and HPLC) for the confirmation of products of the reaction mixture The formate ion formation was confirmed using NMR spectroscopy. After completion of the reaction, 0.6 mL reaction mixture and 0.3 mL D2O was used and analyzed in 600 MHz NMR. The product formate ion chemical shift was confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR; the observed proton signal shifts downfield to 8.4 ppm and 13C chemical shift near 164 ppm (Fig. 8 A and B, ESI, S10). Additionally, the reaction product was confirmed by the FTIR spectrum in the range of 500 to 3000 cm−1 (Fig. 8). Initially, only FTIR of distilled water was recorded for reference purposes, it shows two broad bands at 1650 and 2127 cm−1 (See Fig. 8C (c). However, for confirmation of (COO) and (CH), standard FA 400 mmol in distilled water was used for FT-IR analysis, the vibrational spectra of FA showing highly intense adsorption band around 1217 cm−1 (COO), 1405 cm−1 (CH) and small stretching band at 2552 cm−1 of (-OH) functional groups respectively (See Fig. 8C(b)) [34]. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was analyzed by FTIR and the stretching frequency precisely matched with the stander FA, Where the stretching band at 1026 cm−1 attributed to bending HCOO-, 1167 cm−1 ascribed to COO, 1345 and 1405 attributed to (CH) functional groups are present in the reaction mixture (See Fig. 8C(a)). This NMR and FTIR spectroscopic study concludes that obtained reaction product formate ion is present in the reaction mixture [35,36]. 6 Plausible mechanism Based on experimental results and literature evidence, we proposed a probable catalytic mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation over a Ru-Co3O4 metal oxide catalyst with Et3N (triethylamine) as a base (Scheme 4 ). Initially, Et3N captures gaseous CO2 molecules and may form a zwitterion carbamate intermediate, which is also a CO2 source in the liquid phase [37]. Some chemisorbed CO2 molecules can be transferred to the Ru-Co3O4 catalytic interfaces. Simultaneously, other low-coordinated Ru nanoparticle sites were also involved in activating and dissociating the H2 molecule to generate activated (-H) hydride species. Then Ru interface (-H) hydride species act as nucleophiles and transfer toward the electrophilic carbamate intermediate and reduce this species and form FA [38], but in the presence of amine base, it is stable in zwitterion form. Afterward, the formate ion is formed, which further gets protonated from the basic media to be converted into formic acid. Conclusion In conclusion, significantly lower wt.% of Ru oxide supported on Co3O4 oxide catalyst is synthesized by traditional co-precipitation followed by hydrothermal method and used for hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid synthesis. The non-bicarbonate route for the direct catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid synthesis using cubic Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst with Et3N additives is reported. The series of Ru-Co3O4 catalysts was characterized by various physicochemical methods. The hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid is optimized by varying reaction conditions, including catalyst loading%, temperature, base, gas ratio, and reaction time. The extraordinary catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 using a Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst selectively formed formic acid with high TON of 182. The highest formic acid yield of 250 mmol at 120 °C was obtained in just 6 h, and the catalyst exhibits excellent recyclability and stability under high pressure. Furthermore, the reaction forwarded from the deleterious interaction of Et3N in a water solvent forming a carbamate intermediate. It is a promising approach for direct CO2 hydrogenation and has significant implications in CO2 conversion chemistry. coredata.dc:description: The concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere is rapidly increasing, posing serious environmental concerns. It is preferable to use CO2 as a feedstock for fine chemicals and fuel synthesis to address this challenge successfully. Herein, we report the synthesis of bimetallic oxide composite with significantly lower wt.% of active Ru loaded on spinel cubic phase Co3O4 oxide support. The synthesized catalyst formed cubic Ru-Co3O4 (Ruthenium and Cobalt oxide) nanocrystalline surface morphology with active Ru+3/+4 and Co+2/+3 oxidation states under hydrothermal conditions. The synthesized Ru-Co3O4 oxide catalyst facilitated the reduction of CO2 to formic acid under tailored conditions. The 2.9 wt.% Ru-Co3O4 catalyst exhibited highest formic acid yield (250 mmol) with a high turnover number of 182 under the mild reaction conditions, 1:1 CO2 and H2 (62 bar) gas pressure, 120 °C in 6 h. Ru-supported Co3O4 catalyst captures CO2 through the base. The activated CO2 is then hydrogenated to formic acid. The catalyst can be reused for multiple cycles without losing any activity due to its alkali tolerant properties. The study offers a simple synthesis and efficient industrially viable heterogeneous catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Direct hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid using Ru supported Co3O4 oxide as an efficient heterogeneous catalyst
